PIONEER EXPERIENCES: A GENERAL QUESTIONNAIRE

NOTE: Please print all proper names and place names in capital letters. If you are not sure the name is correct as you have given it, please say so. It is quite acceptable to have someone else do the writing at your dictation.

23. Is there any particular experience of pioneer days that stands out in your memory which you would like to record? One experience I had when I was about 12 years old, my father & I were on the way to the farm just taken up eight months ago. Eastern and as we were going up to put up hay we had a hay rack on the wagon also hay rakes & mower behind and about four o'clock in the PM we started to cross the river about 5 miles west of Edmonton and we got in the middle of the river and got stuck tight so deep way down the bank probably tugged till they broke the whips twice and father had to unhitch the team and ride one of the horses back to the river to get an ash pole to make another try but he got home before dark.

24. Did you travel about much in the early years? (for business, attending church, visiting friends, etc.) How often? How far? By what means of travel? By wagons or buggy or sleigh in winter. We did a considerable amount of visiting friends and going to church in summer in a log building built by the men of the neighborhood. Food and money was sent from relatives in East to buy furniture, lumber, etc. It was used for school also, it was finally torn away in a storm I forget the date, it was the school I got most of my education as I did not get to school in Edmonton we were 8 outs out and it was too far to attend.

31. When (if ever) did you first begin to buy through the mail order catalogues? What kind of articles did you buy in this way? Indicate also what fraction of your total purchases were by mail order and any changes in the proportion of purchases made by mail order since the pioneer period.

We did not do much buying out of town in the early days as money was scarce for one thing and we had to make our a lot of clothing and my grandparents continued to send a lot of yarn or material to be made up. My mother always made stockings out of or on any times made us knit sweaters that were very warm in winter with a pair of mittens.
